before_start: {"blocks":[{"key":"fkpj","text":"Select a set of SNP loci to include in your SNP panel. Prepare a fasta file with one 145bp sequence per locus. SNP loci can be selected from any genomic resource with information on polymorphism. If such resources do not exist, they can be generated from various protocols (see for instance Delord et al. 2018).","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"jfmp","text":"The number of samples to be genotyped should ideally be a multiple of 96","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"eicu0","text":"Choose a sequencing technology that allows reaching 100x read depth per locus per sample","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
description: {"blocks":[{"key":"b5hmg","text":"Many research questions in ecology and evolution require balancing sampling strategies between their spatial (how many populations? on which geographical, environmental gradients?), temporal (diachronic approaches), and genomic (how many and which loci?) dimensions. High-throughput molecular biology protocols often offer very good genomic coverage, but this is often only achievable at the expense of other sampling dimensions. This has led to the development of targeted genotyping strategies for SNP locus sets, in addition to whole or reduced genome sequencing strategies. We here present an adaptation of a protocol developed by the University of Melbourne for genotyping rare variants in human oncology to non-model species for use in ecology and evolution. Hi-Plex is an amplicon sequencing technique (sensu Meek \u0026 Larson 2019) in which all loci are co-amplified in a multiplex reaction before Illumina or Ion-Torrent sequencing (we used Illumina). Intermediate steps include dual indexing of individual samples used for demultiplexing.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
guidelines: {"blocks":[{"key":"96s2","text":"The Hi-Plex protocol is adapted for population genetic studies using SNPs or microhaplotypes. It is an amplicon sequencing technique (sensu Meek \u0026 Larson 2019) in which all loci are co-amplified in a multiplex reaction before Illumina or Ion-Torrent sequencing (we used Illumina). Depending on the number of loci and samples, and given actual reagent and sequencing costs, multilocus genotypes at up to 400 loci can be obtained for about 10 to 15€ per sample.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5q9in","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
keywords: SNP genotyping, SNP panel, genotyping by sequencing, Illumina, Ion Torrent

{"blocks":[{"key":"d2d2u","text":"Foreword","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":8}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"40njd","text":"The protocol that is described hereafter is adapted from Nguyen-Dumont et al. (2013) and Hammet et al. (2019). In this Summary section, potential alternatives to the protocol are mentioned in italic. These alternatives are not described later on (from section 2 onwards).","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":189,"length":9}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8g31c","text":"","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ackm6","text":"Protocol aim","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":12}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"rhd","text":"The Hi-Plex protocol we describe allows the co-amplification and subsequent sequencing of targeted SNP panels (up to 456 SNPs in our trials), and runs through different steps: the synthesis and preparation of gene specifics primers (GSPs) and adaptors (TSITs); a selective multiplex amplification of the SNP panel in a two-step PCR that allows building amplicons, the pooling of PCR products, a second PCR to increase the number of amplicon copies, interrupted with clean-up steps; quality control of the pooled libraries and their sequencing with custom sequencing primers. The sequencing-specific sequences included in the library constructions allow for both Illumina or IonTorrent sequencing but we only tested and thereafter show the protocol for Illumina Miseq sequencing.","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":575,"length":125},{"style":"italic","offset":777,"length":1}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2g4ed","text":"","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7t5uh","text":"Gene specific primers (GSPs) ","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":29}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bfg3f","text":"GSPs are forward and reverse oligos designed from target fragments of 145bp for each SNP. Each resulting Gene Specific Primer (GSP) is built from a target specific sequence and a common heel used to add individual index and sequencing oligos (TSIT).","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6r3ka","text":"","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ct1th","text":"Adaptors (TSITs)","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":16}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9eh9b","text":"TSITs are adaptors that consist of a complementary sequence to the GSP common heel, a barcode, and a specific sequence for Illumina sequencing (P5/P7) for a total of about 60 bp for each TSIT A and TSIT P. The use of a combination of this 2 barcodes allows the specific identification of the DNA samples.","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"b2s3","text":"","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"97i1s","text":"Library preparation","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":19}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3ueg0","text":"The first PCR uses a high fidelity hot start taq polymerase and is made of two phases. In the first phase, a pool of all GSPs (50 µM) is used, to which TSIT adaptors are added for the second phase. The first PCR phase starts with 8 cycles with 2 successive hybridization temperatures (TM) at 58˚C and 60˚C, followed by 4 cycles at 58˚C. The second phase includes 4 cycles with a TM at 66˚C. The reaction is stopped by adding 100 mM EDTA at 72 ˚C and putting on ice.","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7qegl","text":"","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"d01m0","text":"The amplifications are pooled (the pooling unit is a 96-well plate) and purified using magnetic beads. Then, the second PCR is carried out using a high fidelity taq polymerase and the two Illumina's primers P5 and P7 at TM = 58 ˚C. The amplified fragments (250-300 bp) are size-selected by electrophoresis from an agarose gel colored with EtBr followed by extraction with a commercially available silica column or from an automatically size-selection system such as the PipinnTM prep. ","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sup","offset":476,"length":2}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2n8ea","text":"","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8kakg","text":"The use of EtBr is essential if size selection from agarose gel is performed. SybrSafe reagent, for example, generated a lot of non-specific amplicons. This suggests that SybrSafe does not allow for clean separation of migrated fragments on agarose gels.","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":254}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"71qim","text":"","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"17dmt","text":"    ","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"9uskb","text":"Quality controls and sequencing","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":31}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cdv8j","text":"Each library is checked on a Fragment Analyzer™ to estimate the purity of the amplification products. Library concentration is then measured by KAPA qPCR on a LightCycler according to the manufacter protocol. All libraries are finally pooled together in equimolar quantities for sequencing performed on a Miseq platform (Illumina).","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6dnkb","text":"","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"63v9a","text":"   ","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"image","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"8DA89030BD9311EDBB3A47F9D4D25FD1","height":197,"id":369355,"is_video":false,"legend":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"64am7","text":"Simplified schemes of PCR steps ","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}},"mime":"image/png","original_name":"image.png","placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/miypb2rtf.jpg","shadow":true,"source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/miymb2rtf.jpg","type":1,"webp_placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/miynb2rtf.webp","webp_source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/miykb2rtf.webp","width":550}},"1":{"type":"image","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"AE978080BD9311EDBB3A47F9D4D25FD1","height":116,"id":369359,"is_video":false,"legend":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"9642l","text":"Simplified scheme of sequencing step","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}},"mime":"image/png","original_name":"image.png","placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/miytb2rtf.jpg","shadow":true,"source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/miyrb2rtf.jpg","type":1,"webp_placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/miysb2rtf.webp","webp_source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/miyqb2rtf.webp","width":550}}}}

warning: {"blocks":[{"key":"4id85","text":"Reagents and samples should be stored at -20 ˚C and placed in the refrigerator at 4 ˚C until defrosted, ideally the day before any manipulation. To limit the risk of degradation of the primers and adaptors, avoid multiple freeze-thaw cycles by preparing multiple aliquots.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dq1jl","text":"Clean lab bench before work according to lab policy (example: Bleach/ethanol, DNAZap 1, DNAZap 2).","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9bn0e","text":"Materials can be decontaminated in UV box.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1gbkq","text":"Working under a PCR workstation or in a sterile lab is recommended. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3pm0q","text":"Avoid potential contamination of PCR products by using filter tips.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c3ccr","text":"Lab coat and gloves required","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9oiv5","text":"The use of ethidium bromide requires a specific waste treatment and implies to respect general rules to avoid contamination of benchwork, materials and lab technician.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
